title: 111_s1819
content: The Act is titled the "International Civil Rights Center and Museum Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress acknowledges the significance of the Greensboro sit-in and the subsequent wave of nonviolent protests against segregation in the United States. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum, located at the site where the sit-in movement began, will serve as an archival and teaching facility preserving the legacy of the civil rights movement for future generations. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum will open on February 1, 2010, marking the 50th anniversary of the sit-in movement. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 silver coins in commemoration of the opening of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act will have designs emblematic of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum, with inscriptions including the year "2010" and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant entities. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may mint coins only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin. Surcharges go to the International Civil Rights Center and Museum for program development. The Comptroller General can audit the Museum's expenditures.
